channel.title: WinterLove In IDE
channel.description: Hi, so this weird WinterLove client I found is quite strange. I'm using BlueJ because my computer sucks and I needed a starter IDE. The client is split into two main sections src and bin folders, but BlueJ can only read a project if both java files and class files are in one folder and not separate. So I made a new folder and copied each of the class and java files into it into one massive folder so that blueJ could properly read it. When I opened up the project, I tried finding a way to run the client and obviously the first thing I went to was the class/file named "client" the only problem though is that when I run it it's just displaying a console window and it says it's an applet. I know that the client can run and everything can work someway I just don't know how because the client came with a .bat run file and .bat compile file, the compile bat didn't work but the run file to get the client up and going did. So what am I missing here or what did I mess up on? Is it possible I just ran the wrong file? If so what file should I run to get the client running in an IDE? Thanks - EJ

item.title: WinterLove In IDE
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

EJ:

I know, having the class and java files in one super massive folder is just bad and poor organization but I just need it done - you obviously have never used bluej

No, clearly I haven’t. And if it’s making you do that, it’s probably not a very good IDE in general, and you should consider switching…

Read full topic

item.title: WinterLove In IDE
item.dc:creator: @EJ1 EJ
item.description:
@EJ1 wrote:

I know, having the class and java files in one super massive folder is just bad and poor organization but I just need it done - you obviously have never used bluej

item.title: WinterLove In IDE
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

That was a mouthful…

I’m actually really confused how your IDE requires the class files to be in the same directory as the java source files… Because that is not how projects should be set up.
The source should be in src (or a folder of similar meaning) and the compiled binaries should be in the bin folder (or similar).

When you opened the project in the IDE, did you make sure to select the folder containing the src and bin folders?

Read full topic

When I opened up the project, I tried finding a way to run the client and obviously the first thing I went to was the class/file named “client” the only problem though is that when I run it it’s just displaying a console window and it says it’s an applet.
